Drinking at Hopkins
In the state of Maryland, an individual
must have been born by June 30, 1964, in
order to legally drink alcoholic beverages.
This law reflects the gradual increase in the
drinking age from 18 to 21, and was initiated
primarily to reduce the incidence of drunken
driving. While the legislation was passed
more than two years ago, the issue remains
a sticky one for colleges and universities
throughout the state. This is due to the fact
that, for the first time, the majority of college undergraduates are underage.
Colleges are faced with the responsibility
to adopt regulations which reflect their interpretation of the drinking age law. Some
institutions have chosen to ban alcohol from
all campus events. Others have elected to retain drinking policies already in existence.
The Johns Hopkins University administration has maintained that all universityaffiliated functions will uphold the law.
This is an admirable stance, but not a simple one. True, the university must obey the
law. Yet, at the same time, it must accomodate those students who may legally drink.
Rather than eliminating alcohol entirely, the
administration should solicit student input
in search of a mutually acceptable policy.
It seems there has been definite progress
in this direction. Meetings have been scheduled with interested students and groups, in-

Letters

cluding class officers and the inter-fraternity
council. Such action is commendable and
should be supported strongly.
Some individuals and organizations,
however, continue to oppose adherence to
the law. They feel that the university should
condone drinking, or at least merely ignore
it. Their principal reason is the fact that
underage students will drink, regardless of
regulations. Additionally, they maintain that
students will be forced off campus in search
of liquor and, if access to a car is available,
the initial purpose of the law, the prevention
of drunken driving, will be subverted.
These are substantial claims and must be
considered seriously. It is doubtful that the
administration believes that students will not
drink merely because a law exists against it.
Alcohol is traditionally an integral part of
the college experience, especially at Hopkins.
Nevertheless, the decision to drink or to drive
after drinking is an individual one. We, as
adults, must accept the responsibility for our
actions.
Johns Hopkins, however, has a much
broader responsibility. An institution cannot espouse maturity and integrity and, at
the same time, assist its constituents in
disregarding the law, either blatantly or
surreptitiously.

An Absence of Human Rights
by Bill Meeker
In a front-page series currently running in the
Washington Post, staff writer
Benjamin Weiser has been
revealing some rather shocking
facts about the standard-ofliving, or the lack thereof, at
the Rosebud Indian Reservation in South Dakota. Weiser's
title, Injustice at Rosebud,
becomes a polite understatement in contrast to the gross
lack of human compassion that
exists. His article points out the
consignment of a whole ethnic
group, a Sioux tribe, to
subhuman status. In the first
two installments of the series,
the readership of the Post
learned that "seven of every 10
jobless,"
Sioux
are
"some....live in shacks and old
cars," that its physicians are
largely "...unfit, unqualified,
unsuitable, and in some cases,
unlicensed...," that violence,
poverty, disease, and squalor
are "intense." Further description of the situation at Rosebud
in this article would be needless
duplication; Weiser's series
should be read closely by any
interested readers. What is very
important about these articles is
the broader problem that
becomes apparent: the fact that
Rosebud, while it is "....not
typical of America's 265 Indian
reservations...," stands as

....a chilling example of what
can happen in this country
when the most basic civil liberties and essential institutions do
not exist or are allowed to
deteriorate."
What happens when we
understand that groups of U.S.
citizens like the Sioux are
denied the fundamental rights
of which Americans are so
proud? A basic, almost naive
assumption can be made: the
American political system does
not work for all its citizens. For
some, the patriotic, flag-waving
mentality that pervades an election year becomes somewhat
more than hollow. However,
many of the people who
become concerned about
discrimination and civil rights
violations, those very people
who have the capability to actually do something to help oppressed and disadvantaged people, invariably lapse into
cynicism. It seems to be the
popular attitude to have; it is
popular to be a "lost generation" person. The pervading attitude is to ignore politics, to
say that all politicians are
worthless sycophants of one
special interest group or
another. Although it is true that
many voters must choose "the
lesser evil" when participating
in an election, is it impossible
to choose a candidate who at
least appears to favor aid and

justice for groups like the Indians of Rosebud? Is it unlikely that a person who truly
believes in "justice for all"
could be found, no matter how
long it takes? A vote in
November's general election is
the very least that any concerned voter should give, if he or
she really hopes to change the
inequities of society.
Is there more that anyone
can do to change the conditions
of life for the disadvantaged? It
is ridiculous to expect that any
one person, even the President,
can completely right all the
wrongs that exist in this country. All the Federal funds in the
United States Budget alone cannot help anyone without people
to manage, direct, and perform
the work that needs to be done.
It does not matter whether the
money and materials come
from the "private sector" or
from Federal programs; the
fact is that nothing will be accomplished unless a majority of
Americans actually care enough
to get involved. All the
editorials, speeches, campaign
promises, and plans that can be
created, are worthless without
public support and involvement. Complacency, contentment with the status quo,
poisons any impetus for
change. In the end, only one
question remains: what are you
going to do?

Drinking at Hopkins
In the state of Maryland, an individual
must have been born by June 30, 1964, in
order to legally drink alcoholic beverages.
This law reflects the gradual increase in the
drinking age from 18 to 21, and was initiated
primarily to reduce the incidence of drunken
driving. While the legislation was passed
more than two years ago, the issue remains
a sticky one for colleges and universities
throughout the state. This is due to the fact
that, for the first time, the majority of college undergraduates are underage.
Colleges are faced with the responsibility
to adopt regulations which reflect their interpretation of the drinking age law. Some
institutions have chosen to ban alcohol from
all campus events. Others have elected to retain drinking policies already in existence.
The Johns Hopkins University administration has maintained that all universityaffiliated functions will uphold the law.
This is an admirable stance, but not a simple one. True, the university must obey the
law. Yet, at the same time, it must accomodate those students who may legally drink.
Rather than eliminating alcohol entirely, the
administration should solicit student input
in search of a mutually acceptable policy.
It seems there has been definite progress
in this direction. Meetings have been scheduled with interested students and groups, in-

cluding class officers and the inter-fraternity
council. Such action is commendable and
should be supported strongly.

however, continue to oppose adherence to
the law. They feel that the university should
condone drinking, or at least merely ignore
it. Their principal reason is the fact that
underage students will drink, regardless of
regulations. Additionally, they maintain that

actions.

An Absence of Human Rights
by Bill Meeker
In a front-page series currently running in the
Washington Post, staff writer
Benjamin Weiser has been
revealing some rather shocking
facts about the standard-ofliving, or the lack thereof, at
the Rosebud Indian Reservation in South Dakota. Weiser's
title, Injustice at Rosebud,
becomes a polite understatement in contrast to the gross
lack of human compassion that
exists. His article points out the
consignment of a whole ethnic
group, a Sioux tribe, to
subhuman status. In the first
two installments of the series,
the readership of the Post
learned that "seven of every 10
jobless,"
Sioux
are
"some....live in shacks and old
cars," that its physicians are
largely "...unfit, unqualified,
unsuitable, and in some cases,
unlicensed...," that violence,
poverty, disease, and squalor
are "intense." Further description of the situation at Rosebud
in this article would be needless
duplication; Weiser's series
should be read closely by any
interested readers. What is very
important about these articles is
the broader problem that
becomes apparent: the fact that
Rosebud, while it is "....not
typical of America's 265 Indian
reservations...," stands as

....a chilling example of what
can happen in this country
when the most basic civil liberties and essential institutions do
not exist or are allowed to
deteriorate."
What happens when we
understand that groups of U.S.
citizens like the Sioux are
denied the fundamental rights
of which Americans are so
proud? A basic, almost naive
assumption can be made: the
American political system does
not work for all its citizens. For
some, the patriotic, flag-waving
mentality that pervades an election year becomes somewhat
more than hollow. However,
many of the people who
become concerned about
discrimination and civil rights
violations, those very people
who have the capability to actually do something to help oppressed and disadvantaged people, invariably lapse into
cynicism. It seems to be the
popular attitude to have; it is
popular to be a "lost generation" person. The pervading attitude is to ignore politics, to
say that all politicians are
worthless sycophants of one
special interest group or
another. Although it is true that
many voters must choose "the
lesser evil" when participating
in an election, is it impossible
to choose a candidate who at
least appears to favor aid and

justice for groups like the Indians of Rosebud? Is it unlikely that a person who truly
believes in "justice for all"
could be found, no matter how
long it takes? A vote in
November's general election is
the very least that any concerned voter should give, if he or
she really hopes to change the
inequities of society.
Is there more that anyone
can do to change the conditions
of life for the disadvantaged? It
is ridiculous to expect that any
one person, even the President,
can completely right all the
wrongs that exist in this country. All the Federal funds in the
United States Budget alone cannot help anyone without people
to manage, direct, and perform
the work that needs to be done.
It does not matter whether the
money and materials come
from the "private sector" or
from Federal programs; the
fact is that nothing will be accomplished unless a majority of
Americans actually care enough
to get involved. All the
editorials, speeches, campaign
promises, and plans that can be
created, are worthless without
public support and involvement. Complacency, contentment with the status quo,
poisons any impetus for
change. In the end, only one
question remains: what are you
going to do?

computers. He believes people
are depending on them as if
they were a true source of
knowledge. Truesdell believes
that we must originate all inquiry, and avoid letting the
computer lead any inquiry.
Truesdell points out that
much of the current scientific
inquiry, from the physical
